title: Francis Barlow (artist)
text:
Francis Barlow (c. 1626 – 1704) was an English painter, etcher, and illustrator.
He ranks among the most prolific book-illustrators and <a href="Printmaking">printmaker</a>s of the 17th century, working across several <a href="genre">genre</a>s: natural history, hunting and recreation, politics, and decoration and design.
Barlow is known as "the father of British sporting painting"; he was Britain's first <a href="Animal%20painter">wildlife painter</a>, beginning a tradition that reached a high-point a century later, in the work of <a href="George%20Stubbs">George Stubbs</a>. He was furthermore a pioneer in the <a href="history%20of%20comics">history of comics</a> by creating "<a href="A%20True%20Narrative%20of%20the%20Horrid%20Hellish%20Popish%20Plot">A True Narrative of the Horrid Hellish Popish Plot</a>" (c. 1682), a picture story about the life of <a href="Titus%20Oates">Titus Oates</a> and the <a href="Popish%20Plot">Popish Plot</a>, which is told in a series of illustrated sequences where the story is written underneath them and the characters depicted on those images use <a href="speech%20balloon">speech balloon</a>s to talk. While it is not the first example of its kind in history, it is one of the oldest which is signed.
Life.
Barlow was born c. 1626 in <a href="Lincolnshire">Lincolnshire</a>.
The exact day of Barlow's death is unknown but he was buried on 11 August 1704. <a href="Joseph%20Strutt%20%28engraver%20and%20antiquary%29">Joseph Strutt</a> records that Barlow died in poverty: "not withstanding all his excellency in design, the multitude of pictures and drawings he appears to have made, and the assistance also of a considerable sum of money, said to have been left to him by a friend, he died in indigent circumstances."
Work.
Barlow's first major work was the illustration (via twelve plates) of poet <a href="Edward%20Benlowe">Edward Benlowe</a>'s "Theophila" (1652). In Barlow's favour, <a href="Arthur%20Henry%20Bullen">Bullen</a> said in 1885 that "the volume [was] valued rather for the engravings than for the text." According to <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a>'s <a href="Chetham%27s%20Library">Chetham's Library</a>, no two copies of Benlowe's "Theophila" are the same, and no copy survives in good condition. The <a href="Victoria%20and%20Albert%20Museum">Victoria and Albert Museum</a> holds two different copies, one of which includes an original drawing by Barlow.
Barlow designed the one hundred and ten <a href="woodcut">woodcut</a>s for <a href="John%20Ogilby">John Ogilby</a>'s translation of "<a href="Aesop%27s%20Fables">Aesop's Fables</a>", published in 1665, several of the plates of which Barlow etched himself.
<a href="Hugh%20James%20Rose">Hugh James Rose</a> observed in the early 19th century that Barlow's "chief merit [. . .] as a designer, lay in his exactness in the portrayal of birds, fishes, and animals of all kinds, which are executed in a spirited, and in many instances a masterly manner." One example of this gift is in a set of twelve prints by <a href="Wenceslaus%20Hollar">Wenceslaus Hollar</a> of engravings after drawings by Barlow, entitled "Several Ways of Hunting, Hawking, and Fishing, invented by Francis Barlow, engraved by W. Hollar, 1671", published by John Overton.
A 2011 article in "<a href="History%20Today">History Today</a>" explored the <a href="subtext">subtext</a> in examples of Barlow's work: though his wildlife paintings are superb works of art in themselves, they are, at the same time, "full of rich metaphors that shed light on the anxieties and concerns of a Britain emerging from the horrors of <a href="English%20Civil%20War">civil war</a>". A case in point is "A Decoy", Barlow's <a href="allegory">allegory</a> on the threat posed to England by <a href="Catholic%20Church%20in%20England%20and%20Wales">Roman Catholicism</a>.
In the years leading up to the <a href="Glorious%20Revolution">Glorious Revolution</a>, Barlow became the prime designer of <a href="political%20satire">political satire</a> in support of the <a href="Whigs%20%28British%20political%20party%29">Whigs</a>; Whig <a href="Member%20of%20parliament">MP</a> <a href="Denzil%20Onslow%20of%20Pyrford">Denzil Onslow</a> (1642-1721) acquired or commissioned a number of paintings by Barlow, to decorate his <a href="manor%20house">manor house</a>, Pyrford Court. These were more recently housed at <a href="Clandon%20Park">Clandon Park</a>, an 18th-century mansion near <a href="Guildford">Guildford</a>, <a href="Surrey">Surrey</a>, becoming one of the largest collections of Barlow's surviving work. Barlow's (and others') work "miraculously" survived a devastating fire at Clandon Park on 29 April 2015.
Examples of Barlow's work can be seen at <a href="Ham%20House">Ham House</a> (in <a href="Ham%2C%20London">Ham</a>, south of <a href="Richmond%2C%20London">Richmond</a> in London); examples are held, too, by: <a href="Tate%20Britain">Tate Britain</a>, the <a href="National%20Portrait%20Gallery%2C%20London">National Portrait Gallery</a>, the <a href="British%20Museum">British Museum</a>, and the <a href="Victoria%20and%20Albert%20Museum">Victoria and Albert Museum</a>.
Barlow frequently signed the initials of his name, "F.B.", instead of inserting it at full length, sometimes enclosing the initials in a small circle.
Assessment.
Barlow has come to be regarded as a "surprisingly neglected artist". Art historian <a href="Mark%20Hallett%20%28art%20historian%29">Mark Hallett</a> accounts for this by noting that Barlow's time is British art's "forgotten era" - one that "has tended to be overshadowed by the achievements of earlier artists, such as <a href="Anthony%20van%20Dyck">Van Dyck</a>, or those that came later, such as <a href="William%20Hogarth">Hogarth</a>"; Hallett finds this unjust: Barlow made a significant contribution to what "in reality [. . .] was a remarkably rich, vibrant and cosmopolitan period for the visual arts in Britain."
